response: Ipswich Town defeated AZ Alkmaar to lift the trophy after a cup final that saw a win on aggregate. An Ipswich player, Butcher, participated in a 260-mile charity cycling event to Holland in remembrance of the victory. The event raised funds for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, Gertrude, and an unnamed storm caused severe flooding and damage in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The full repair cost is yet to be calculated, but support will be provided through the Bellwin Scheme. However, the local authority must contribute £508,000. A council report disclosed 240 required repair projects, with 114 deemed major. Further work may be needed following underwater bridge examinations.

Thomas Cook Airlines plans to operate a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer, from 4 May to 31 October. The decision was influenced by the success of one-off flights to the US in recent years. This is the first time Scotland will have a regular service to Las Vegas. The airline's addition strengthens Glasgow Airport's long-haul offering and is beneficial for holidaymakers. An extra flight to Tunisia has also been announced.

This text discusses the potential outcomes of football seedings. Teams include England, Wales, and Northern Ireland, with potential groupings being England, Italy, Czech Republic and either Wales or Northern Ireland. These seedings are based on Uefa's national team coefficient rankings including past tournament records. Spain, France, Germany, Portugal and Belgium are other top seeds. The finals draw will take place on 12 December. The Republic of Ireland, Denmark, Norway and Slovenia could potentially face Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden and Hungary in the play-offs.

Damon Smith, a student, denies making or possessing an explosive device in court, but admits to a bomb hoax. Prosecution alleges that Smith created an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) intended to endanger lives on the Jubilee Line train, as it contained ball bearings for increased damaging effect. Smith claims the device was only designed to generate smoke and he added the ball bearings to make it look like a real bomb to gain media attention.

The Mansfield District Council has approved the £250m Lindhurst development despite over 140 objections. The project includes construction of 1,700 homes, a primary school, and a community centre, and promises up to 4,000 jobs. Developers received planning approval amid protests against potential loss of wildlife habitats and worsening congestion. The planning committee decision was split, with the chairman casting the deciding vote in favor.
The UN reports that Europe holds the worst record globally for discarding fish, with nearly a quarter of all catches being thrown back overboard dead due to undesirability by the crew.

HP sold its WebOS operating system to LG, a product it obtained when it purchased Palm in 2011. Despite having launched products with WebOS, poor sales led HP to make the system open-source. LG, one of the earliest major users of the open-source WebOS, intends to use it for their next-generation smart TV. As part of the deal, LG receives the WebOS source code, personnel, documentation, and promotional assets, while HP retains the underlying patents.

Ipswich Town's manager, Mick McCarthy, expressed his fury after striker Joe Pigott's late equaliser for U's in a recent match, describing it as "garbage". Noting similar instances from the past season where the team lost crucial points from winning positions, McCarthy vowed not to tolerate such mistakes. Despite it being a pre-season friendly, McCarthy underlined his disdain for conceding late goals.

Tests on Jane Austen's glasses at the British Library reveal her sight deteriorated significantly, possibly due to arsenic oral medication for her rheumatism. Arsenic, a heavy metal known to cause cataracts, was common in medicines during Austen's time and may have contributed to her death at age 41. The strength of the lenses in her glasses escalated over time, suggesting difficulty in reading or writing before her demise.

Archbishop Justin Welby announced hopes to have a fixed Easter date within the next 5 to 10 years. Despite a 1928 UK act of Parliament allowing for a set Easter Sunday, the date has remained variable based on the moon's cycle. The Archbishop is in talks with global Christian leaders including Pope Francis. Previously, the Vatican approved a fixed Easter date proposal in 1990, but agreement among other Christian churches and governments has not been reached.

A recent survey has indicated a slight decline in business conditions in Northern Ireland, showing reduced output and new orders in April. This marks the fourth decrease in activity over the past five months. However, manufacturing showed signs of growth due to demand in Great Britain. Despite struggles in the retail and construction sectors, firms continue to hire, with employment growth in all sectors, besides construction. The impact of the new Conservative government's plans remains uncertain.

The high street shop in Penarth, Vale of Glamorgan, a UKIP establishment, has been under attack since its opening in November. In response, the party is encouraging its "anarchist friends" to throw eggs at posters of Farage and Penarth candidate John Rees-Evans instead. However, no eggs have been reported thrown since the display of these posters.

The opening night of "One Man, Two Guvnors" at Windsor's Theatre Royal was halted due to flash-flooding. The auditorium was evacuated when water began pouring under the doors. Theatre director Robert Miles confirmed that thanks to quick drying, the following night's show would continue as scheduled. This incident happened amidst heavy rains causing chaos in Berkshire town and London.

Fiji gained independence from Britain in 1970, thereafter experiencing political upheaval owing to rivalry between indigenous Fijians and ethnic Indian communities. In 2014, a former military leader, Frank Bainimarama, who had seized power in a coup eight years prior, became prime minister. Fijian resident Jioji Konousi Konrote was elected president in 2015. Fiji's media is under the control of its government, leading to self-censorship among journalists to avoid harsh penalties.

The Indian government has suspended the results of two students, Ruby Rai and Saurabh Shrestha, due to suspicions of cheating on their examinations. This move comes after a video interview went viral, where Rai, who excelled in political science, said the subject was about cooking. Additionally, Shrestha, the science topper, could not answer a simple chemistry question. They, along with 12 others, must now reappear for a written test and an interview before a panel of experts.

Approximately 30 homeless demonstrators were evicted from their camp at St Peter's Square, Manchester, after the city council was issued a warrant. The protesters, who were raising awareness about homelessness and temporary housing issues, have now set up another camp half a mile away. The council pointed out that maintaining the camp had cost over £88,000 in additional policing, security, and legal costs.

Two debris pieces found separately and sent to Australia for analysis have been confirmed as "almost certainly" from missing Malaysian Airlines flight MH370, according to Darren Chester. The parts were consistent with a Boeing 777 aircraft and were found in locations that align with drift modelling of ocean currents. The search for the aircraft, led by Australian, Chinese, and Malaysian experts, is expected to continue over the coming months. MH370 disappeared in 2014, becoming one of aviation's biggest mysteries.

The RMT union plans two more days of strikes over the ongoing dispute with ScotRail about driver-only trains. The strikes will take place on 24 and 31 July, following unsuccessful talks through the Acas conciliation service. ScotRail argues that a majority of customers already use trains where doors are operated by drivers, and guarantees a second person on board. Over 80% of services are expected to run as usual during the strike, says Transport Scotland.

The Cavaliers won their latest game against the Warriors in the best-of-seven series, making the series 2-1. Kyrie Irving secured 30 points for the Cavaliers. However, the Warriors' Steph Curry only obtained 19 points. Game four is set to take place in Cleveland on Friday. Cleveland lost to Golden State in last year's Finals.

The track by singer Ellie Goulding, "Burn", has topped the UK Single chat, selling 117,000 copies, outperforming its rival, Avicii's "Wake Me Up". Lady Gaga's "Applause" held the fifth position on the list. Goulding's previous highest charting single was her cover of Elton John's "Your Song". On the album chart, Britain's Got Talent duo Richard and Adam Johnson secured the top spot for a third week with their debut record, "The Impossible Dream".

Highland Council will avoid £1.3m of planned cuts but will implement other savings, like changing its sickness absence policy and implementing energy incentives in schools. A proposal from the Liberal Democrats to reduce senior councillors' pay was rejected. The council had voiced concerns over funding cuts being imposed due to the council tax freeze. Despite accepting a £10.3bn funding deal from the Scottish government, local authorities, including Highland Council, believe the tax freeze could strain budgets and result in job cuts.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn has alleged unfair dismissal by HMP Littlehey in Cambridgeshire during an employment tribunal. His dismissal followed complaints from gay prisoners over his reading of Bible verses that condemn homosexuality. Trayhorn argued that his Christian faith and teachings should not have to adapt to contemporary sexual values and that he was later asked to leave his voluntary chapel services and attend a disciplinary hearing for making a "homophobic statement".

The UK Home Office needs to improve its handling of overstayers, or foreign nationals refused the right to remain in the UK, according to independent immigration inspector John Vine. The report also highlights inaccuracies in outsourcing group Capita’s record-keeping of migration refusals. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire conceded there was room for improvement, vowing to implement the report's recommendations.

My Dentist, an NHS practice based in Dolgellau, Wales, is to close on 31 March due to not being able to recruit a dentist for over two years. The town's only other dental clinic is private. The Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board plans to recommission dental services quickly, but warns of a gap between the existing and new services. Meanwhile, it is arranging interim services, including a dental out-of-hours clinic at the local hospital.

A widespread search for 26-year-old Liam Day, involving police and coastguard, was conducted by air, sea, and land, after he went missing while possibly climbing alone near Durlston Country Park. His climbing equipment was found near Anvil Point, with authorities urging anyone with information to come forward. The coastguard suspended the search and his partner, Emily Brown, expressed doubts about Liam's return.

McGuinness is strategizing to counter the all-attacking style of the defending champions in the All-Ireland semi-final at Croke Park, focusing on football prowess over other factors. He led Donegal to their third Ulster title in last four years. His team, All-Ireland champions two years ago, is considered the underdog but McGuinness stresses the importance of faith in the players.

The High Fliers market research company found that in 2015, approximately 1,000 graduates turned down job offers at the last minute. Despite this, the number of graduates hired increased by 3.3%, and starting salaries remained roughly at £30,000. The report also asserted that as the job market becomes stronger, graduates are becoming pickier about their employers. Graduate pay at top law firms, investment banks and accounting firms saw further increase.

A man sustained head and leg injuries after falling into the path of an oncoming train in south-west London around 23:00 BST on Friday. The incident occurred as crowds were departing from Twickenham Stadium following England's World Cup victory over Fiji. Although his condition is not believed to be critical, the station was evacuated and service was temporarily suspended. The circumstances of his fall are under investigation.

Malta, located south of Sicily, has a diverse colonial history, occupied by Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, France, and Britain before gaining independence in 1964. It's a strategic trade location and a popular tourist destination. The population is 419,000 with Christianity being the major religion and Maltese and English the main languages. The current president is Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca, while the prime minister is Joseph Muscat. Malta became a republic in 1974, joined the EU in 2004, and adopted the euro in 2008.

The 34-year-old actor stars in "Demolition," a tragicomedy directed by Jean-Marc Vallee, about an investment banker rebuilding his life after his wife's tragic death. The film premiers at the Toronto International Film Festival, where almost 400 films will be screened. Co-stars include Naomi Watts, Chris Cooper, and newcomer Judah Lewis. This is Vallee's third film at the festival, following "Dallas Buyers Club" and "Wild".

The Belfast Telegraph covers a story about a boy injured in a petrol bomb attack in Newtownabbey. The Irish News focuses on a claim that five Orange Halls have received grants as historical societies, despite criticism of the scheme. The report also covers a story about a boy treating life-threatening epilepsy with cannabis oil in the US. The newspaper also mentions discussion about President Trump’s travel ban. The News Letter discusses the potential prosecution linked to the 1976 Kingsmills massacre.

Action on Hearing Loss, a campaign group, warns against listening to music at high volumes, revealing a third of adults ignore "safe level" on music players, potentially raising their risk of tinnitus. The group further says that tinnitus affects one in 10 people in the UK daily. DJ Paul Oakenfold urged the use of ear defenders at gigs, noise-cancelling headphones, and lowering volume on personal music players as preventative measures. No current cure exists for tinnitus.

In the mixed team event at the Hopman Cup, France emerged as champions. Richard Gasquet's win against Jack Sock and Coco Vandeweghe's loss to Kristina Mladenovic led to a deciding doubles match. Gasquet and Mladenovic defeated the US team, denying them their seventh title. This is the second time France won the Hopman Cup, with the previous win in 2014. The Great Britain team was eliminated in the group phase.

The Australian coach is preparing England's Rugby team to face Ireland in what will be his first home match, after they secured away victories over Scotland and Italy. He believes everyone harbours a rivalry towards England and that is something the team should utilize. He also talks about repositioning Leicester Centre Manu Tuilagi as a 12 once he's back in peak condition post his injury recovery. The coach praises his players' commitment and considers his side a work in progress.

In the six months to end-September, Scottish paramedics treated around 12,000 heavily intoxicated individuals, impacting ambulance services and resources. The Scottish Conservatives revealed these figures, stating that alcohol was a factor in over half of ambulance call-outs during weekends. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde reported the highest number of alcohol-related 999 calls. There are calls for more support for paramedics who deal with such instances, but a shift in personal responsibility regarding alcohol consumption is seen as the ultimate solution.

'Enabling Success', a strategy developed by Employment Minister Stephen Farry and Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster, aims to address the issue of economic inactivity in Northern Ireland. The focus will be on three groups - those with work-limiting health conditions or disabilities, lone parents and people with caring obligations. By 2030, the plan seeks to raise employment levels beyond the UK average.

Billionaire and reality TV star, Mr. Trump, faced extensive criticism for his remarks on Mr. McCain's status as a war hero, triggering outrage across the political party. Despite clarification, he did not apologize. The issue escalated an already existing conflict between the two, triggered by Mr. Trump's controversial comments on Mexican immigrants. These developments occur amid the race for the Republican presidential candidacy, where Mr. Trump has been leading in early polls.

The agent of renowned Canadian author, known best for his baseball-themed fantasy 'Shoeless Joe', announced his doctor-assisted death. The fantasy was adapted into the successful 1989 film 'Field of Dreams'. Kinsella, a winner of the Order of Canada, published over 30 works spanning various genres. After a car crash induced head injury, he lost interest in writing fiction, but he eventually returned to writing. His final work 'Russian Dolls' will be released next year.

Máiría Cahill, a victim of rape who accused the IRA of covering up the assault, has won a by-election to fill the seat left vacant by Jimmy Harte of the Labour party. After her election, Cahill pledged to invite sex abuse organizations to parliament to discuss support for victims and expressed her desire to work for the welfare of victims of abuse and young jobseekers. Cahill was expected to win the election and secured the majority of the votes.

ChildLine, the children's charity, has launched a campaign after receiving calls from 12 to 13-year-olds boys who fear they are addicted to pornography. The campaign, called Fight Against Porn Zombies, was launched following a UK-wide survey showing 20% of 700 children had seen disturbing pornographic images. The charity hopes to address this issue and help children affected by the nature of pornography.

The Mariner Street car park in Swansea will be replaced with a 725-bedroom student block, including a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. At 22 storeys, it will be the second tallest building in the city and is expected to be completed by Summer 2018. This development is viewed as a significant step towards High Street's regeneration and is driven by the growing demand for student accommodation.

The Australian states of Queensland and New South Wales (NSW) were hit by floods due to torrential rain from remnants of Cyclone Debbie. Multiple towns, including the capital of Queensland, Brisbane, and businesses were severely affected with power outages, washed away roads, and damaged properties. The storm system has now moved out to sea.

A software glitch on iPad's used by American Airlines' pilots and co-pilots for viewing flight plans caused delays. Some flights had to return to the gate to connect to Wi-Fi and fix the issue. The company, which went paperless in 2013 to save fuel costs, is investigating the problem's cause. The use of tablets in airlines is common, with some airlines using different devices and software.

Girish Pote, 35, has been convicted by a court in Thane, a Mumbai suburb, for the murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak in 2013. Pote brutally killed Pathak, chopped her body, and confessed his crime to his relatives. Due to the heinous nature of his crime, he will serve a life term beyond the typical 14 years in India. The couple, who had been arguing over money and Pathak's desire to return to France, had a two-year-old son.

Bradford Council has proposed plans for a one-way gyratory along East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to tackle the town's increasing congestion issue. Deputy Council Leader, Val Salter, emphasized the urgency of addressing this issue. The plans will be available for public viewing at the Airedale shopping centre on 11 and 13 June.

23-year-old Thorpe has played seven times this season for the Millers, his last game resulting in a 5-2 loss to Ipswich on November 7. The former Manchester United trainee may debut for Bradford against Millwall this Saturday. Bradford, currently placed seventh in League One, is just outside the play-offs on goal difference.

A radio presenter from Radio Flaixbak tricked Spain's PM, Mr. Rajoy, into a mock conversation with a fake Carles Puigdemont, the Catalan leader. When asked about a meeting, Rajoy agreed, stating he had a flexible schedule. The hoax was revealed soon after Rajoy said he would call back for a meeting. Upon realizing he'd been deceived, Rajoy expressed disappointment, but took the prank in stride.

Discussions took place in the House of Lords regarding the £1 per hour pay rate for detainees at immigration removal centres performing voluntary work. Critics, including Lib Dem Baroness Hamwee, questioned if such a pay rate was fair, but Baroness Williams said it was a way to relieve boredom and wasn't meant to save money. She insisted the benefit was for the detainees, not the service contractors, and said the pay rate was under review.

The Borders Book Festival is set to host the announcement of the Walter Scott Prize winner, a list currently containing Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, Charlotte Hobson, Hannah Kent, Francis Spufford, Graham Swift and Rose Tremain. The shortlist was extended due to the varied nature of the submissions, with the judges praising the historical research and character engagement. The prize was established in 2009, with the winner receiving £25,000 and shortlisted authors being awarded £1,000 each.

Bangladesh is close to its first Test win against England, needing just 33 runs but having only two wickets left. England's Stuart Broad commends Bangladesh's skill and notes England's determination to stay in the game. Broad was run out in the second over and England was soon bowled out for 240. The match is notable for a world record number of reviewed decisions, with a total of 24.

Members of UCU Scotland have voted for strike action regarding job security at the University of Aberdeen's medical school. The union claims the university potentially discriminated against four Asian staff members who faced redundancy following a restructuring. The university denies these claims, saying the staff members have been offered alternative roles at their current pay and grade and ensures that the student exams will not be disrupted by the strikes.

Jay Brenton Liptrot, owner of a property where five people died in a 2012 fire, appeared in court without entering a plea. The victims included a young couple, their baby, and two other children. Melanie Smith is serving a 30-year sentence for starting the fire during a dispute over a hallway. Liptrot will next appear in court in May.

A 34-year old man, involved in a "disgraceful incident" at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base, was freed from custody pending further inquiries. Initially, he was expected to appear at Aberdeen Sheriff Court. The incident was described as "disgraceful" by Police Scotland.

The report by the "Read On. Get On." coalition, including organisations like Save the Children and Scottish Book Trust, indicates that children with poor reading skills could suffer life-long consequences, including fewer qualifications and lower likelihood of further education. To address this, the coalition aims to make sure all 11-year-olds are proficient readers within a generation. The report revealed that 40% of low-income families own fewer than 10 children's books, and encouraged parents to read to their toddlers regularly.

The Giants have successfully secured the future services of two key players, Martinelli and Mark Garside. Martinelli signals his excitement to continue "chasing trophies" in Belfast, while Garside is entering his eighth consecutive year with the team. Head Coach Adam Keefe recognizes their contributions, praising them as great assets for the team. Garside, a two-time league champion and recent World Championship gold winner, is expected to play a pivotal role in the team's pursuit of more silverware.

16-year-old Rasmus Barlow was reported missing on Monday, leading to an extensive police search. His death is not considered suspicious, and a report is being prepared for the coroner's office. Family liaison officers continue to support Barlow's family.

Regina Hungerford, a 55-year-old teacher at Merthyr Tydfil College, was accused of striking a 17-year-old student in her classroom. Although she denied the claim, the Education Workforce Council determined inappropriate contact was likely made. Hungerford's prior conviction for common assault was overturned on the grounds she slammed a notebook on a desk in anger. The council will later decide whether Hungerford will be taken off the teaching register.

On May 4, also known as Star Wars Day, many brands, celebrities, and institutes used the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou for promotions and celebrations. Mark Hamill recreated his Star Wars role, while brands sold goods, Heathrow Airport featured Star Wars-related content, and charities raised awareness. The British Museum showcased a Star Wars exhibit. Even former Dragons Den star, Theo Paphitis, joined in the celebration.

Retired generals and admirals have backed Donald Trump, calling him "more trusted to be commander-in-chief than Hillary Clinton". This news was welcomed by Trump amidst controversies about a political donation to a Florida official who allegedly dropped a fraud investigation against Trump University after receiving the contribution. Also, despite making military support a key issue in his campaign, Trump has repeatedly received criticism from military members.

A 21-year-old player transferred from QPR to the Tykes after their promotion to the Championship last summer, but appeared in only seven league matches. He had a short loan tenure at Colchester from QPR in the 2014-15 season, where he played six times. He recently signed a one-year contract, with a 12-month renewal option, with John McGreal's team.

The new trilogy, The Book of Dust, by author Phillip Pullman will follow the story of Lyra Belacqua from infancy to age 20. The first book is due in October, title not yet released. This follows his successful His Dark Materials series, including the well-known Northern Lights, which sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

The American Red Cross apologized and removed a safety poster from their website after being accused of racism. The poster depicted more black children being "not cool," while more white children were portrayed as behaving sensibly. John Sawyer from Salida, Colorado, highlighted this issue in a tweet. The Red Cross stated they hadn't meant to offend anyone and are committed to diversity and inclusion.

Winkelman has confirmed that Karl Robinson will continue as the manager for the next season despite previous uncertainties. Robinson had been critical about the club's use of funds following relegation and was unable to keep the Dons in the Championship in their first-ever season. Winkelman trusts Robinson's experience and ambition and is optimistic about the upcoming season in League One.

Actors James Cosmo and Karen Gillan have been named as honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). Cosmo, known for his role in Braveheart, and former Dr Who star Gillan, who is now a director, expressed their excitement and honor to be appointed in the new roles. Gillan, originally from Inverness, mentioned her creative connection to Edinburgh city.

Tottenham left-back Danny Rose has apologised for comments made in a recent interview, claiming he and his team-mates are underpaid and that the team needs to sign well-known players. He added the timing and tone of his remarks were "ill-judged". In response, Manager Mauricio Pochettino stated that he forgives Rose, and that the footballer still has a future with Tottenham.

The International Ski Federation (FIS) has penalized Vanessa Vanakorn, a British violinist and skier, for alleged manipulation of results to secure her participation in the Sochi Olympics. Vanessa, who represented Thailand under her father's last name, and five officials are subjected to penalties after an investigation into four Slovenian pre-Olympic qualification races. Vanessa, who finished last in her event, has appealed the ruling to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.

In a soccer match, Macclesfield Town defeated Eastleigh 1-0. The sole goal was scored by Rhys Browne in the seventh minute. Despite other goal attempts from both sides, none were successful. The game witnessed a number of substitutions and a yellow card shown to Eastleigh's Adam Dugdale.

Warner Bros TV has not reached a salary agreement with actors Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, Kaley Cuoco, Simon Helberg, and Kunal Nayyar from the CBS sitcom. The cast members reportedly seek up to $1m per show, potentially making them the highest paid actors on US television. Despite negotiation issues, they are still expected to return to work. The long-running sitcom will continue until at least 2017.

Matthew Cobden was hospitalized with serious injuries following a car crash in North Warnborough that killed Alexander Worth. Cobden, from Walton-on-Thames, Surrey, has been granted unconditional bail and will appear at Winchester Crown Court on 26th July. No other vehicles were involved in the crash. The incident drew sympathy from District Judge Philip Gillibrand towards Alexander's family.

Refugees spoke at a Queen Street gathering in the wake of UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians displaced by war. Notable activities took place, including a demonstration in Swansea's Castle Square, a planned human chain in Caernarfon, and a forthcoming Wales refugee crisis summit. Hannah Wharf of the Welsh Refugee Council praised the move, but local authorities stressed they would need financial help to meet costs.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, also known as Popeye, was a top hitman for notorious Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar, confessing to killing 300 people. He served two decades in a high-security prison and walked free recently, under probation for four years. His release has divided Colombia, with some believing he should pay more for his crimes. He is known to have testified against ex-justice minister Alberto Santofimio, who ordered the killing of a political rival.

In a recent 22-8 defeat, Wolves' rugby league player Kurt Gidley became the first to wear a camera during a game. However, technical issues led to the device's removal at half-time. The camera, mounted on a vest inside Gidley's shirt, was meant to provide a unique perspective of the sport. Despite early issues, Sky Sports, who broadcast Super League games, plan to continue their experiment with on-player cameras.

A man has been reported to the procurator fiscal for alleged sexual offences at Auchinlee care home in Campbeltown. The Care Inspectorate is working with the police and monitoring the situation. The allegations involve a 76-year-old woman who was reportedly sexually assaulted by an 82-year-old man. The Inspectorate has urged anyone with concerns about a care service to contact their helpline.

Des McDaid testified to the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry about his experience of sexual abuse in orphanages in Ireland and Australia. At eight-years-old, he was one of 16 boys sent from Ireland to an Australian orphanage where he experienced repeated sexual abuse by older boys, Christian Brothers religious order members, and a teacher. His testimony is part of a wider investigation into child abuse in religious and state-run institutions in Northern Ireland from 1922 to 1995.

World number 45 lost to the reigning US Open champion, despite taking the first set. Swiss 31-year-old will play against third seed Kei Nishikori in the semi-finals. Canadian top seed and defending champion beat Rafael Nadal to reach the last four against Bulgarian seventh seed Grigor Dimitrov. British number four was knocked out at the quarter-final stage of the Chennai Open by French fifth seed Benoit Paire.

The 50-year-old lead musician of the Irish rock band U2 was treated at a neurosurgery clinic in Munich and will recuperate in Ireland. Their upcoming US tour date on June 3 has been postponed, and the band's Glastonbury appearance is uncertain. The band plans to reinstate any disrupted dates and advises fans to check their website for updates. U2's 360 Degree tour was the most profitable globally in 2009.

A helicopter crash between Abergavenny and Raglan has resulted in two passengers and the pilot being hospitalized. The incident, which occurred around 15:25 BST, led to the closure of the road and alerted air accident officials. Two South Wales fire engines managed to contain a leak of approximately 120 litres of on-board fuel.

Angela Scott will replace Valerie Watts as chief executive of the city council in July. Currently the council's director of corporate governance, Scott brings financial expertise and leadership skills to face the upcoming financial challenges. Her new salary will be £144,685. Council leader Barney Crockett expressed delight at the decision, citing her as the ideal candidate to lead the council's workforce and bring service excellence.

In a recent game, a 26-year-old Manchester United footballer collided with Wahbi Khazri, resulting in injury and sidelining him for several weeks according to team manager Louis van Gaal. This leaves only Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love as the team's only fit full-backs. Love just made his first-team debut, while Borthwick-Jackson debuted in November. The injured player, Darmian, joined United from Italian side Torino last summer.

Kenneth Harper's rape convictions were overturned by the Court of Criminal Appeal in Edinburgh due to insufficient mutual corroboration between two offences that happened nearly eight years apart. The court found no 'extraordinary features' to link the two incidents, despite the prosecution arguing both cases involved significantly younger, vulnerable women. Harper is to serve a three-year sentence for remaining charges of assault and reckless behaviour.

The actor expressed excitement about his role as Tommy Butler in "The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale", which portrays the infamous heist from a law enforcement perspective. This follows "A Robber's Tale", showcasing the robbers' viewpoint. Luke Evans will star in the latter film as the lead planner. Chris Chibnall, the executive producer and writer, praised the casting. The actor had previously won accolades for his performances in "Iris Murdoch" and "Lord Longford".

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was attacked by a group of 20-25 girls in Central Park, Peterborough. The fight, filmed and posted on social media by the victim's mother, has been viewed over 680,000 times. The victim said the other girls wanted to fight her because they believed she was "being cheeky". Cambridgeshire Police are investigating the incident, which occurred between 20:00 and 21:00 BST.

The Maccabees scored their first number one album with Marks To Prove It, finishing slightly ahead of Lianne La Havas' Blood. The Very Best of Cilla Black reached its highest ever chart position at number 14 after her death. Meanwhile, One Direction's new single, Drag Me Down set a UK record for highest first-week streams. The top five was completed by Calvin Harris and Disciples, Black Magic by Little Mix, Lost Frequencies and Years & Years.

Zayn Malik, former member of One Direction, has left the band to seek a normal life, sparking rumors of the group disbanding. However, remaining band member Liam Payne reassured fans that they will continue as a four-piece. Despite Malik's departure after stress and personal issues, there's no negative sentiment between him and his ex-bandmates. Malik is believed to be working on a solo album with producer Naughty Boy.

Police Scotland has been alerted about a leak that revealed the names of witnesses and details about an alleged gun hit on social media. Investigations are underway to understand the full extent of the situation.

Steven Flynn was jailed for 16 months after admitting to breaking into McDiarmid Park, home of St Johnstone's football team, intending to steal money to pay off his drug debts. Police initially dismissed an alarm activation at 02:40, thinking a window had been left accidentally open. However, a cleaner discovered evidence of a break-in, leading to a full investigation which positively identified Flynn using CCTV footage.

Mr Farage, unaware of the error, was seen standing in front of a misspelled UKIP poster during his visit to Sleaford in support of UKIP candidate Victoria Ayling. The error was pointed out on social media. The BBC contacted UKIP but received no response. The Lincolnshire seat is vacant due to the resignation of Conservative MP Stephen Phillips over policy differences with the government. A by-election is set for Thursday.

Blair Henderson scored early on, putting the hosts in the lead. Despite Stirling's best efforts, including a noteworthy attempt by Moses Olanrewaju, they couldn't equalise due to skillful defending from Johnny Fairbairn. A handball resulted in Brian Martin being sent off, further disadvantaging Stirling. The scoreline remained the same after Sean Dickson missed a crucial penalty.

Fiona Barnes, who had falsely claimed she had terminal cancer, was sentenced to 15 months in prison for stealing £24,713 from Preston's Space Centre and perverting the course of justice. At her Proceeds of Crime hearing, she was ordered to repay £1 as she was proven to have no money. The Centre, which supports children with physical, learning, or emotional issues, called the ruling an "outrage" and a "complete insult".

31-year-old experienced footballer, Adam El-Abd, who started his career at Brighton and played for Bristol City until last season, has joined Shropshire under Micky Mellon. He had been loaned to Bury, Swindon, and Gillingham before. Joining him in Shropshire is former Bury full-back Joe Riley. Their induction comes as part of Mellon's efforts to rebuild his squad for the new League One campaign.

Jones, the coach of his squad, emphasised the importance of developing more leaders within the team for the 2019 World Cup victory. He plans to cultivate eight or nine guys who are consistently leaders. Jones suspects today's athletes surviving in sheltered environments to be an issue. The coaches are working towards building potential key players. Dylan Hartley, who led England's unbeaten 2016, will captain again in Six Nations, with Owen Farrell as a potential replacement.

38-year-old Chris Rogers will play in the next season's County Championship, delighting Matthew Maynard. Rogers is expected to bat at three, providing high-quality play and stability. The Sydney-born player's experience may also nurture young talent within Somerset's squad. Both Maynard and Rogers are hopeful of his excellent performance in the coming season.

A Range Rover crashed into a property on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, causing serious structural damage and forcing two people to evacuate their home. An investigation is underway as the police appeal for witnesses. No serious injuries were reported, although the driver suffered minor injuries. The road was temporarily closed but no arrests have been made.

The demolition of a building on Kingsway, which started in October 2015, got delayed due to more asbestos than initially estimated. The council acquired this site aiming to develop Kingsway into a business district. While all internal works are done, and scaffolding is established for external demolition, the full project is set to conclude by the spring.

Following an unsuccessful goal appeal in Rovers' recent match, coach Bowyer has called on Football League chiefs to implement goal-line technology, similar to the Premier League. Bowyer argues that the financial stakes are too high not to use such a system, which would eliminate ambiguity and make the game fairer. Fulham manager Kit Symons also supports the introduction of this technology in the Championship.

The 19-year-old athlete, Kapustka, has been signed by top-flight champion City manager, Claudio Ranieri for a five-year deal at a reported £7.5m. Kapustka, who impressed in Euro 2016, joins the Foxes in Stockholm and is Ranieri's fifth summer signing after keeper Ron-Robert Zieler, defender Luis Hernandez, midfielder Nampalys Mendy, and forward Ahmed Musa.

The Burrell Collection, a museum in Pollok Country Park, will close for a multi-million pound redevelopment and reopen in 2020. The renovation will make the museum more energy-efficient, and create additional exhibition space, so that 90% of the 8,000 items can be viewed by the public. Some collection items will be displayed at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery during the refurbishment. The total cost of the project is expected to be between £60m and £66m.

Farmers supplying chickens to a poultry processing company have benefited from a heating subsidy scheme, replacing their LPG heating systems with wood chip boilers. Concerns have been raised regarding the operation of the scheme, but the company insists it is advocating for "responsible use of heat". The firm met with officials to find a budget solution for the scheme. The finance minister rebuffed proposed cost control measures, terming them a "sticking plaster" on the scandal.

A man's body was found in a field near Belsyde Avenue on Saturday at around 11:25. Police are currently conducting inquiries to identify him. A post-mortem examination is scheduled to ascertain the cause of death.

On 7 June 2016, Ipswich beat AZ Alkmaar to win the cup final, after Butcher and his team achieved an aggregate win of 3-0 at Portman Road, despite a subsequent 4-2 defeat in Holland. In commemoration of this victory, a charity cycling team, including Butcher, completed a 260-mile round trip to Holland, raising funds for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, Gertrude, and an unnamed storm caused severe flooding and major damage in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The total repair costs are unknown but the local authority will receive support from the Bellwin Scheme, contributing £508,000. A council report identified 240 tasks, 114 considered major, needed for repairs. Additional necessary works may be uncovered once bridge inspections below water level occur.

Thomas Cook Airlines will launch a weekly flight from Glasgow to Las Vegas between 4 May and 31 October next year. The new service comes after successful one-off flights to the US in recent summers. The airline will use its Airbus A330 fleet for the route. In addition, Thomas Cook announced an additional flight to Tunisia available three times a week in summer 2015.

England, Spain, France, Germany, Portugal, and Belgium are top seeds in the UEFA's national team coefficient rankings, with England in pot one, and Wales and Northern Ireland potentially in pot four. The Republic of Ireland could end up in pot three or four, depending on their playoff results. Other playoff seeds include Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, Hungary, Denmark, Norway, and Slovenia. The final draw is scheduled for 12 December.

Damon Smith, on trial at the Old Bailey, has denied making a bomb with intention to endanger life, but admitted to creating a bomb hoax. Prosecutors say Smith's device, found on a train by passengers, contained ball bearings for shrapnel to "increase the destructive effect". Smith claimed he meant only to produce smoke and make the device look real to have the train stopped and the incident reported in the news. The trial continues.

Mansfield District Council approved the controversial £250m Lindhurst scheme via the chairman's casting vote. With over 140 objections, the project was primarily opposed for potential loss of countryside and the ability to deliver promises. The scheme, the largest ever applied to the council, includes 1,700 homes, a primary school, a cemetery, a community centre, and a park, promising to add up to 4,000 jobs and significant economic benefits. Protesters showed disdain at the decision.
The UN has reported that Europe has the highest rate of discarded fish globally, with nearly a quarter of all catches being thrown back dead due to unwanted species being caught.

HP sold the WebOS operating system to LG after it failed to gain traction on its devices, like the TouchPad tablet. LG intends to use WebOS in its upcoming smart TV technology. The deal included the WebOS source code, engineers, documentation, and promotional websites, but HP retained patents linked to WebOS. The decision amounted from a relationship formed when LG took the opportunity to develop for WebOS, hoping it leads to user-friendly advances in their devices.

Ipswich manager, McCarthy, expressed his frustration after his team lost a lead to U's striker Joe Pigott in the 89th minute. McCarthy criticised his team's performance, notably their recurring problem of losing points from winning positions late in games, as happened last season against Brentford, Nottingham Forest, and Bolton. Despite the recent match being a pre-season friendly, McCarthy revealed his disappointment, especially since his team had possession of the ball when the goal was scored.

Tests on three pairs of glasses owned by Jane Austen held at the British Library revealed her eyesight significantly deteriorated, possibly due to arsenic poisoning from medicines she may have taken for rheumatism. This might also have contributed to her early demise at age 41. The glasses, despite their age, are still in good condition and showed increasing lens strength, indicating Austen's vision issues. The library is now seeking optometrists' opinions on this theory.

Archbishop Justin Welby announced after a meeting of Anglican primates that a fixed date for Easter, potentially the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April, may be established within 5 to 10 years. Though the UK Parliament passed an act for a fixed Easter Sunday in 1928, it was never activated. The archbishop has been in discussion with Pope Francis and other Christian leaders regarding this change, which has met with 15 past unsuccessful attempts.

Ulster Bank's latest survey indicates a slight decline in Northern Ireland's private sector activity, marking the fourth dip in five months. While manufacturing saw a six-month peak in growth and orders due to demand in Great Britain, retail and construction reported significant decreases. Despite current economic uncertainty, staffing levels increased in April at the quickest rate in seven months across most sectors, excluding construction. Future business conditions will be influenced by the new Conservative government's economic plans and policies.

A UKIP shop in Penarth, Vale of Glamorgan, has faced opposition since its opening in November. The party encouraged "anarchist friends" to target eggs at posters of Farage and candidate John Rees-Evans. According to a UKIP spokesman, no eggs have been thrown since the poster placement.

Theatre Royal in Windsor was forced to cancel the opening night of "One Man, Two Guvnors" due to flash-flooding from heavy rainfall. The water threatened the stage and resulted in an evacuation of the attendees. Despite some damage, Theatre Director, Robert Miles, assured that the venue was dried out and Wednesday's performance would go ahead. This show, performed by the Windsor Repertory Company, is part of a six-week festival celebrating over two centuries of theatre in Berkshire.

Fiji has witnessed considerable political upheaval due to rivalry between indigenous Fijians and the ethnic Indian communities since its independence from Britain in 1970. Josaia Voreqe "Frank" Bainimarama, a former military leader and advocate for equal rights for the ethnic Indian community, was elected Prime Minister in 2014. Meanwhile, the first non-indigenous and parliamentary-elected President, Jioji Konousi Konrote, was elected in 2015. The government regulates the media which has resulted in self-censorship.

The Indian government has suspended exam results of two top-scoring students - one erroneously claimed political science concerned cooking, another couldn't answer simple chemistry. Their interviews went viral, leading to the suspension and a retest for them and 12 other high-performers. This follows last year's scandal of parents aiding cheating in exams. The government's introduction of anti-cheating measures seemed initially successful due to lower pass rates.

Manchester City Council evicted about 30 people protesting homelessness from St Peter's Square, following a lost appeal against the issued eviction warrant. Some demonstrators relocated half a mile away, establishing a new camp in St Anne's Square. Tensions arose from disruptive behaviour, causing over £88,000 in additional costs for the council and police. Despite these issues, the council expressed its commitment to addressing homelessness, stating its homelessness service has offered support and accommodation to the protesters.

Two pieces of debris found separately by the public have been analysed in Australia and are said to be "consistent with panels from a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 aircraft". This evidence suggests that the MH370 flight, which disappeared in 2014 carrying 239 passengers, likely landed in the Indian Ocean. Despite this breakthrough, the search, led by Australia with Malaysia and China, will continue in hope of finding more wreckage unless significant new evidence appears.

The RMT union is planning two more strikes amid disputes with ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour has urged Transport Minister Humza Yousaf to intervene and help resolve the issue. The RMT wants train door operation to be controlled by guards for safety reasons, but ScotRail claims 59% of passengers already use trains where doors are operated safely by drivers. Transport Scotland assures that 80% of services will run normally during the strikes. Passengers are advised to check for information on the ScotRail website.

The Cavaliers trail 2-1 in the best-of-seven series after losing the first two matches but winning the third, with crucial contributions from Kyrie Irving and LeBron James. Golden State's Steph Curry scored only 19 points, leading to criticism from coach Steve Kerr about team readiness. The teams will face off again in Cleveland on Friday. Last year's finals saw the Cavaliers lose to Golden State.

The track "Burn" by Ellie Goulding sold 117,000 copies, making it number one on the official charts and surpassing her previous highest charting single "Your Song". Other notable chart entries include Lady Gaga's "Applause" at five and Arctic Monkeys' "Why'd You Call Me When You're High" at eight. In the album chart, Richard and Adam Johnson's debut record "The Impossible Dream" retains the top spot for three consecutive weeks.

Planned cuts of £1.3m were avoided but other savings will be enforced by altering the council's sickness absence policy and improving schools' energy efficiency. A proposal to reduce senior councilors' pay was defeated but funding for deprived areas, homeless support, and women's aid groups may be cut. The council tax freeze has placed strain on budgets, leading to potential job cuts and service reductions. All 32 Scottish local authorities have accepted a £10.3bn funding deal from the government, although many did so grudgingly.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn, a Pentecostal Christian minister and gardening supervisor at HMP Littlehey, alleges unfair dismissal after reading Bible verses at prison services that prompted complaints from gay prisoners. Trayhorn, who was prevented from volunteering at chapel services and faced disciplinary action, resigned in 2014 due to stress, claiming harassment due to his faith. His case against the Secretary of State for Justice is ongoing.

The Independent Inspector of Immigration, John Vine, urged the Home Office to improve its handling of immigration "overstayers." He warned that failure could erode public trust. Despite previous errors in outsourcing group Capita's classification of refusal records, the number of overstayers has remained static. However, Vine identified further records of nationals residing in the UK without permission, and called for considerable improvements from the Home Office to manage the immigration enforcement caseload. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire acknowledged the need for improvement.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau, Wales, is closing due to struggles recruiting a dentist in the past two years, leaving local patients with only private practices. Both local officers and the clinical director stress the importance of addressing dentist shortages in rural areas. The Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board plans to re-commission dental services, possibly needing temporary measures in the meantime, and re-allocate funding from any reduced or ended NHS dental commitments.

26-year-old Liam Day went missing after a solo climb near Durlston Country Park. Despite extensive searches by police and coastguard, there's little hope for his return, as stated by his partner, Emily Brown, on Facebook. The search has now been suspended. Police requests anyone who saw a man climbing the cliffs in the area to contact them. Climbing equipment was later found west of Anvil Point.

In preparation for the All-Ireland semi-final at Croke Park, McGuinness is devising a plan to counter the defending champions' aggressive play style. This highly tactical game, according to McGuinness, relies 100% on the football players, who he trusts completely. Regardless of being rated as 8/1 outsiders, McGuinness, who led Donegal to a third Ulster title, remains unfazed, trusting his team's ability and focusing on perfecting their game.

A report by High Fliers reveals that in 2015, about 1,000 graduates declined job offers at the last minute, causing issues for employers. 20,000 students were recruited, mainly at the start of their final year. As competition increases amongst top employers, talented graduates are receiving multiple offers and becoming more selective. Despite a 3.3% increase in hiring, starting salaries for graduates remained around £30,000, while top law firms and banks saw a further increase.

A man sustained head and leg injuries after falling onto train tracks near Twickenham Stadium following England's victory over Fiji in the World Cup's opening game. The incident resulted in the station's evacuation and temporary suspension of train services. The man's condition is not considered critical and he was taken to St George's Hospital. British Transport Police is investigating how the man came to fall onto the tracks.

Malta, located south of Sicily, has a history of colonial control by various powers including the Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, France, and Britain. It gained independence in 1964. Malta is a crucial trading post due to its strategic location and relies heavily on tourism as its main income source. The country's official languages are Maltese and English, and its dominant religion is Christianity. As of 2014, Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca is the president, while Joseph Muscat has been Prime Minister since 2013.

The film "Demolition", starring a 34-year-old who must rebuild his life after his wife's tragic death, premiered at a film festival where almost 400 films will be shown. Directed by Jean-Marc Vallee, who has had success at the same festival in previous years, the film also features Naomi Watts, Chris Cooper, and newcomer Judah Lewis. The festival traditionally starts awards season and concludes with an awards ceremony.

The Belfast Telegraph reported on a boy who suffered injuries from a petrol bomb attack. The Irish News drew attention to grants awarded to five Orange Halls under a controversial scheme for cultural and educational societies, and to a boy undergoing treatment for life-threatening epilepsy in the U.S., utilising cannabis oil, an illegal treatment in the UK. The paper also covered reactions to President Trump's travel ban, and questioned whether Theresa May knew of the plans beforehand.

Action on Hearing Loss warns that excessive loud music can induce tinnitus, affecting 1 in 10 people in the UK daily. A poll revealed a third of adults ignore "safe levels" on music players and half listen to music for up to six hours a day. Paul Oakenfold, supporting the campaign, highlights the need for ear defenders at concerts and avoiding high volumes on personal devices. Currently, there is no cure for tinnitus.

France claimed victory in the mixed team event at the Hopman Cup, after Richard Gasquet and Kristina Mladenovic defeated their American opponents in the deciding doubles match. This denied America a seventh title, marking France's second win; their first was in 2014. Great Britain's team did not advance past the group phase.

Australian coach Eddie Jones feels the rivalry towards England as they prepare to face Ireland in his first home match, following away wins over Scotland and Italy. Jones see Manu Tuilagi's future for England as an inside centre. She commends his team's commitment and initiative, and prepares them for Ireland's unique playstyle. As of now, England and France are tied at the top of the Six Nations table.

In six months, paramedics in Scotland treated approximately 12,000 extremely intoxicated individuals, according to statistics obtained by the Scottish Conservatives. Over half of all weekend ambulance call-outs were alcohol-related, significantly impacting ambulance services. The figures highlight the serious societal issue of alcohol abuse in Scotland, which not only negatively affects individuals but also diverts critical resources. The highest number of alcohol-related emergencies occurred in Greater Glasgow and Clyde, followed by Lothian and Lanarkshire.

The 'Enabling Success' strategy, launched by Employment Minister Stephen Farry and Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster, aims to reduce Northern Ireland's economic inactivity rate of 27%, compared to the UK average of 22%. The targets are people with work-limiting health conditions or disabilities, single parents, and those with caring responsibilities. The strategy's aim by 2030 is to increase Northern Ireland's current employment rate (68.6%) above the UK's average (73.4%).

Reality TV star and billionaire, Mr. Trump, faced wide criticism for his remarks about veteran and senator Mr. McCain, saying he only considered him a hero because he was a POW. These comments were condemned by fellow party members. Trump later clarified, but didn't apologize, stating he didn't appreciate McCain's work with veterans. McCain, who was held captive for over five years in Vietnam, has yet to respond. Trump's popularity in early polls is thought to decrease over time.

The acclaimed author, best known for his baseball-themed novel Shoeless Joe, which was transformed into the film Field of Dreams, died in a doctor-assisted manner, a legal practice in Canada. Post a car crash-induced head injury, he shifted his focus from fiction writing to online Scrabble, though he resumed writing later. His final work, Russian Dolls, is scheduled for release next year. He was a recipient of the Order of Canada, one of the country's top accolades.

Máiría Cahill secured a Labour party seat in a by-election, receiving 122 of 188 votes. The prominent seat was previously held by Jimmy Harte. Earlier, Cahill publicly exposed her rape case allegedly involving an IRA member. Despite unsuccessful prosecution of her assailant, a delay in proceedings led Northern Ireland's Public Prosecution Service to apologise. Renouncing her earlier republican beliefs, Cahill plans to focus on supporting abuse victims and young job-seekers in her senator role.

ChildLine, a children's counselling charity, has launched a campaign named the 'Fight Against Porn Zombies' to address the troubling number of 12 to 13-year-olds who fear they are addicted to pornography. The campaign was initiated after the charity's offices in Cardiff and Prestatyn fielded calls from distressed boys. A UK-wide poll of 700 children showed that 20% had seen pornographic content that shocked or upset them.

Mariner Street car park in Swansea will be transformed into a 725-bedroom student block, featuring a nightclub, gym, offices, bars, restaurants, and shops. Being the second tallest building in Swansea, the tower's construction commences this year, slated for completion by summer 2018. The council recognizes the growing demand for student accommodation and believes the project marks a significant step in High Street's regeneration.

Floods have partially submerged areas of Queensland and New South Wales in Australia due to remnants of Cyclone Debbie. Local towns and Queensland’s capital, Brisbane, suffered damage, with businesses being swamped and residents even using surfboards to navigate streets. An evacuation order was issued in Beaudesert. The extreme weather resulted in tens of thousands losing power, damaged infrastructure, and displacement of wildlife. Currently, the storm system has moved out to sea.

A glitch in the iPad software used to view flight plans caused disruption to American Airlines flights, forcing pilots to return to the gate for a Wi-Fi connection to rectify the issue. The airline went paperless in 2013, a move estimated to save $1.2m in fuel annually. The software issue is under investigation, with passengers impacted soon redirected to their destinations. Other carriers have also begun the switch from paper to tablet, introducing additional features and potential cost savings.

Girish Pote, 35, was convicted for life by a court in Thane, Mumbai, for the 2013 murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak. Pote killed Pathak, who held a French passport, and dismembered her body over disputes regarding money and her wish to return to France. The couple lived in Mumbai's Bhayander area and had a two-year-old son. Pote confessed his crime to relatives who then informed the police.

Bradford Council has proposed a clockwise one-way gyratory system on East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to address the town's escalating congestion issue. According to Deputy council leader Val Salter, urgent measures are deemed necessary. The plans will be exhibited at the Airedale shopping centre on 11th and 13th June.

23-year-old Thorpe, having played seven times for the Millers this season, could possibly debut for Bradford against Millwall on Saturday. His last appearance resulted in a 5-2 defeat against Ipswich on November 7. Currently, Bradford holds the seventh position in League One, missing the playoffs due to goal difference.

A radio presenter on Radio Flaixbak impersonated Carles Puigdemont, the Catalan leader, in a prank call to Spanish PM Mr Rajoy. Rajoy agreed to meet the impersonator, revealing his free schedule. Unaware of the prank, Rajoy declared his intent to maintain national unity despite disagreement with Puigdemont, who wishes for Catalonia's secession. Upon learning of the prank, Rajoy expressed disappointment but took the joke well.

Baroness Williams has defended the £1 per hour pay rate for volunteer detained immigrants, stating it is not a money-saving scheme, but a method to relieve boredom and meet their recreational and intellectual needs. Lord Rosser suggested that such wages could save the government or the managing firms around £300,000 a month. Despite this, Williams reiterated that the benefit is for the detainees and the standard pay is under review, with a report expected by year's end.

Seven authors, including Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, and Rose Tremain, are shortlisted for the £25,000 Walter Scott Prize, to be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose. The list was extended due to the range of the entries, offering readers unique subject matters and characters. The jury praised the novels for encapsulating history in unforgettable ways. The final decision will be made ahead of the festival on 17 June. The prize, founded in 2009, also awards £1,000 to each shortlisted author.

Bangladesh is on the cusp of its first Test win over England, needing just 33 more runs with two wickets left. The opening Test of the two-match series is notable for a world record number of decisions being reviewed, at 24 so far. England's Stuart Broad praised both teams' skills and determination, noting the game's high tension level. England completes its Bangladesh tour with the second Test before heading to India in November for a five-Test series.

Members of UCU Scotland at the University of Aberdeen's medical school voted to strike amid concerns about job security, launching a petition. All four staff members involved in the dispute are of Asian origin, raising questions of discrimination. Despite the university's disappointment and arrangements to prevent disruption during exams, the strike will proceed. The university, arguing that it had offered alternative employment and denied any compulsory redundancies, asserted it upheld equal opportunity employment.

Jay Brenton Liptrot, the owner of a property in Prestatyn where five people were killed in a fire in 2012, appeared in court but did not plea. The victims included a couple, their young son, and two relatives. Melanie Smith has been sentenced to at least 30 years for starting the fire due to a dispute over a shared hallway. Liptrot is due back in court in May.

A "disgraceful incident" occurred at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay. Police Scotland reported that a 34-year-old man connected to the event was expected to appear in Aberdeen Sheriff Court. However, the Crown Office later released him from custody pending further investigations.

The "Read On. Get On." report indicates that kids lagging in reading skills could face lifelong disadvantages. The report's supporters, including Save the Children and the Scottish Book Trust, aim to have all 11-year-olds read proficiently within one generation, and urge parents to read to their kids for 10 minutes daily. The report also highlights the glaring gap in access to books among low and high income families and its impact on children's reading skills later in life.

A 30-year-old Giants player has re-signed with the franchise, joining fellow team member Mark Garside who is also committing to another year. Garside, a significant player with two league titles and a recent World Championship gold, will be playing for the Giants for his eighth consecutive year. Both players are eager to remain with the club and their coach, Adam Keefe, expresses excitement about their follow-up season.

16-year-old Rasmus Barlow was reported missing by his father, leading to a comprehensive police search. However, his death is now being investigated, with no suspicion of foul play at present. The coroner's office is preparing a file, and the family of the teen is receiving ongoing support from police liaison officers.

Regina Hungerford, a teacher at Merthyr Tydfil College, is accused of striking a 17-year-old student in a fit of anger. While Hungerford admits to losing her temper, she denies physical contact, claiming she slammed a notebook on the desk. Despite her appeal, the Education Workforce Council found the accusations against her more likely than not and deemed her actions unacceptable. Her standing in the register is under review.

Many big brands, celebrities like Mark Hamill, and institutions like the British Museum are leveraging Star Wars Day, May 4th, using the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou for promotion and awareness-raising efforts. These include attempts to sell products like flight tickets and pizzas, plug companies or raise awareness for charities, among others. Heathrow Airport received notable praise for its Star Wars-themed tweet.

A group of retired generals and admirals endorsed Republican nominee, Donald Trump, believing he has the temperament to be commander-in-chief. Trump, under scrutiny for a donation to a Florida official who dropped fraud charges against Trump University, called the endorsement an honour. The letter also stated Trump is more trusted than Hillary Clinton. Both Trump and Clinton will participate in a national security forum. Meanwhile, Clinton released an ad criticising Trump's questionable stance on veterans.

A 21-year-old football player, formerly of QPR, joined the Tykes after their promotion to the Championship. However, he made only seven league appearances. Previously, he had a short loan spell at Colchester in the 2014-15 season. The left-sided player recently signed a one-year contract, with a possible 12-month extension, at John McGreal's team.

Phillip Pullman will released a new trilogy, The Book of Dust, in October and it will continue the story of Lyra Belacqua from the His Dark Materials series, starting from her infancy to her 20s. His Dark Materials, which began with "Northern Lights" in 1995, sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

John Sawyer from Colorado called out the American Red Cross on Twitter for a pool safety poster depicting more black children as "not cool" and white children as "cool". The Red Cross quickly apologized, stating their commitment to diversity and inclusion, and said it was not their intention to offend. The poster has since been removed from their website and will no longer be printed. This hasn't, however, stemmed online reaction.

Winkelman confirms Karl Robinson will remain as manager for the next season despite relegation issues. Robinson, who had previously led the club to a League One promotion, blamed improper use of money received for midfielder Dele Alli for the club's relegation. Winkelman acknowledges mistakes in recruitment and emphasizes the increased pressure is indicative of the club's growth. He ensures ongoing investment in Robinson, trusting his commitment to the club.

Scottish actors James Cosmo, known for "Braveheart", and Karen Gillan, former "Dr Who" star now turned director, are the new honorary patrons at the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). Both expressed their excitement and honor at these roles. Gillan highlighted her creative connection with Edinburgh, having moved there at 16 to study acting.

Tottenham left-back Danny Rose apologised for his comments suggesting that he and his team-mates are underpaid, and that the club should sign high-profile players. His remarks were labelled ill-judged, but manager Mauricio Pochettino forgave him, affirming his future at Tottenham remains intact. Tottenham hasn't made any summer signings, unlike rivals, and recently sold right-back Kyle Walker to Manchester City. Rose, who's made 144 appearances for the club, is currently sidelined with a knee problem.

The International Ski Federation (FIS) imposed a punishment on Mae, a Singapore-born British violinist who represented Thailand, accusing her of manipulating results to secure a place at the Sochi Olympics. Mae, who competed under her father's surname 'Vanakorn', finished last in the Giant Slalom. Mae along with five officials were investigated over four Slovenian races. The Court of Arbitration for Sport is considering her appeal against the decisions.

In a tightly contested match, Macclesfield Town secured a 1-0 victory over Eastleigh. Rhys Browne scored the decisive goal in the seventh minute, with the game opening up with chances for both sides afterwards. Despite Macclesfield having a second goal disallowed and Eastleigh nearly equalising in the 70th minute, the score remained 1-0 until the final whistle. Several substitutions occurred throughout the match, with Rhys Browne replaced by Danny Whitaker for Macclesfield.

Warner Bros TV is in dispute with the main actors of the CBS sitcom, over salary increases from $325,000 to $1m per episode. If an agreement isn't reached in the next two weeks, production could be delayed. Despite disagreements, the actors are expected to return to work for the show that has been extended until at least 2017. Such a pay rise could make them the best paid TV actors in the US.

Matthew Cobden appeared in Basingstoke Magistrates' Court concerning a fatal car crash that resulted in the death of Alexander Worth. The crash occurred between Newlyns and Lodge Farms at North Warnborough, with no other vehicles involved. Cobden, who suffered serious injuries from the incident, was granted unconditional bail. The case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court for 26 July.

At a Queen Street gathering, refugees and the Welsh Refugee Council called for immediate action to resettle 20,000 displaced Syrians in the UK. Demonstrations also took place in Swansea and a human chain is planned in Gwynedd. Authorities in Wales have expressed willingness to accommodate refugees but seek financial assistance. UK Prime Minister, David Cameron, announced priority help for vulnerable Syrian camp children. Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones is to host a summit on the refugee crisis.

John Jairo Velasquez, aka Popeye and a top hitman for Pablo Escobar, walked free from high-security prison on probation after serving two decades for his role in killing 300 people and involvement in 3,000 more. He also provided evidence against ex-Justice Minister Alberto Santofimio, convicted of ordering the killing of presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan. There's division in Colombia over his release, with some insisting he has not fully paid for his crimes.

Wolves' Kurt Gidley became the first rugby league player to wear a camera during a game, providing a unique perspective of the sport. Despite removal at half-time due to technical issues, the notion is seen as positive with intent to replicate it in the future. Gidley's coach, Tony Smith, insisted the technology was not to blame for their defeat and the experiment was conducted for the right reasons.

Police were called to Auchinlee care home in Campbeltown following an alleged sexual offence involving an 82 year-old man and a 76 year-old woman. The Care Inspectorate, which regulates care homes, is working closely with the police on the ongoing investigation. The safety and well-being of residents remain a top priority. The public have been urged to report any care service concerns to their helpline.

Des McDaid testified to the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry about his experiences as a child migrant from Derry, Ireland to a Clontarf orphanage in Perth, Australia in 1953. He recounted instances of sexual abuse by older boys, members of the Christian Brothers religious order and a lay teacher. McDaid waives his right to anonymity and wanted the feeling of "helplessness" to be remembered from his narrative. The inquiry is investigating child abuse in religious and state-run institutions in Northern Ireland from 1922 to 1995.

The reigning US Open champion won against world number 45, with a score of 6-7 (2-7) 6-4 6-4 and will now play third seed Kei Nishikori in the semi-finals. Defending champion Milos Raonic defeated Rafael Nadal 4-6 6-3 6-4 to reach the last four. He will play against Bulgarian seventh seed Grigor Dimitrov. At the Chennai Open in India, British number four Aljaz Bedene lost 6-3 6-0 to French fifth seed Benoit Paire.

A 50-year-old musician from a renowned Irish rock band has been hospitalized in Munich for a neurosurgery and is to recuperate at home in Ireland afterwards. The band's US tour, initially starting in June, and their appearance at Glastonbury may be affected. The band's manager urges fans to keep track of updates on the band's website. The band is known for its profitable tours, earning about $109m in 2009.

An incident occurred between Abergavenny and Raglan at 15:25 BST where two passengers and a pilot were hospitalized. The air accident officials were notified, and the road was shut due to the presence of two fire engines from South Wales. Roughly 120 litres of fuel leakage on board was successfully contained by the crews.

Angela Scott will succeed Valerie Watts as Chief Executive of the city council in July. Scott previously held the position of the council's director of corporate governance and was praised for her financial expertise and leadership. She is prepared to tackle upcoming financial challenges, aiming to deliver service excellence and work on Aberdeen's priorities. The salary for the role is stated to be £144,685.

A 26-year-old player from United was injured in a collision during a game against Black Cats, resulting in a dislocated injury that will take several weeks to recover from. This leaves the club short on full-backs with only Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love, who recently made his first-team debut, fit to play. United's boss, Louis van Gaal noted the shortage of full-backs, jesting that he might have to employ a 13-year-old player.

Kenneth Harper's rape convictions were overturned by judges at the Court of Criminal Appeal in Edinburgh, due to issues raised about the use and validity of mutual corroboration as evidence. The defence argued that the two alleged incidents, separated by eight years and differing circumstances, were too dissimilar to corroborate each other. Harper continues to serve a three-year sentence for remaining charges of assault and reckless behaviour.

The actor is excited to play Tommy Butler in "The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale", following "A Robber's Tale" which will depict the heist from the robbers' perspective. He describes Butler as a fascinating 'old school' copper. The actor won an Oscar in 2001 and a Bafta in 2007. He appreciates the script for revealing the real story behind the high-profile robbery. The executive producer described his casting as a "dream".

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was attacked by a group of 20-25 girls in Central Park, Peterborough, after being accused of being "cheeky" at school. The brawl, which left her bruised, was filmed and uploaded to Facebook by her mother in hopes of identifying the assailants. The video has been viewed over 680,000 times. Local police are investigating the incident, which occurred between 20:00 and 21:00 BST.

Indie band The Maccabees achieved their first UK number one album with "Marks To Prove It". The track broke UK streaming records for first-week plays. Following her death, Cilla Black's "The Very Best of Cilla Black" reached its highest ever position at number 14. "Drag Me Down", One Direction's first single since Zayn Malik's departure, saw surprise release. The top five also included tracks from Calvin Harris and Disciples, Little Mix, Lost Frequencies, and Years & Years.

Despite Zayn Malik's departure and breakup rumors, One Direction will continue as a four-piece band. Malik left to "live like a normal 22-year-old" and is thought to be working on a solo album after reports of infidelity. The band, however, thanks fans for their support and continues their On the Road Again tour, including an upcoming European leg. Malik insists there is no animosity with his former bandmates.

Police Scotland is investigating a leak that led to witnesses' names and details of an alleged gun incident being disclosed on social media. The forces were alerted about the communications being shared on social media and are currently examining the full context of the situation.
