Steven Flynn broke into McDiarmid Park stadium to find money to clear drug debts. Despite an initial alarm, police initially disregarded signs of break-in. A cleaner later discovered the theft when she noticed signs of disturbance. Flynn, with 120 previous convictions, stole keys and £20 from a charity box. Identified from CCTV footage and caught with a muddy crowbar, Flynn admitted his crime. Subsequently, he was sentenced to 16 months in jail for his actions.

During a visit to Sleaford to support UKIP candidate Victoria Ayling ahead of a by-election, Nigel Farage was filmed in front of a UKIP poster with a spelling error in the word "Hykeham". The poster was mocked on social media and pointed out by BBC political correspondent Chris Mason. The by-election was called after the resignation of Conservative MP Stephen Phillips due to "irreconcilable policy differences" with the government.

The hosts took the lead with Blair Henderson scoring at 24 seconds from Michael McKenna's assist. Stirling's Moses Olanrewaju was blocked by Johnny Fairbairn, missing a score opportunity. Brian Martin was dismissed for a handball in the area, but despite this, Stirling could not equalise, as Sean Dickson missed a penalty shot.

Fiona Barnes, 55, was jailed for 15 months for fraudulently acquiring £24,713 from Preston's Space Centre and faking terminal cancer. She falsified documents that showed non-existent grants of up to £800,000. Despite this, she was ordered to pay back only £1 as she had no money, leading the centre to label the ruling a "complete insult". The centre was saved by Manchester's Creative Support and provides for children with various difficulties.

Experienced footballer Adam El-Abd, previously released by Bristol City, is joining Shropshire in Micky Mellon's squad. El-Abd, with over 300 appearances for Brighton and loan spells at Bury, Swindon, and Gillingham, will join Joe Riley in the preparation for the new League One campaign. The squad's other notable players include Oliver Lancashire, Ryan McGivern, Gary Deegan, and Jim O'Brien.

Jones, England's rugby coach, believes that his team needs consistent leaders to become World Cup contenders in 2019. There's a need to develop eight or nine individuals into leader roles, something that he believes is a common struggle within the sporting community due to young athletes' sheltered environments. Players have started individual leadership programs to help cultivate this growth. Dylan Hartley, the current captain, will continue to lead, with Owen Farrell as a potential replacement.

38-year-old Rogers is set to play in the next season's County Championship, much to the delight of Maynard. Rogers will bat at three, providing support for opening duo Marcus Trescothick and Tom Abell. Despite retiring from Test cricket, Rogers' input to Somerset's squad is viewed as vital, with hopes that his experience will benefit the younger players in the team, such as Abell. Maynard expects an outstanding season from Rogers.

A Range Rover crashed into a house on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, causing serious structural damage and forcing two residents to evacuate. The incident occurred just before 02:00 BST and the road was later closed for an hour. The driver sustained minor injuries but did not require hospitalization. No arrests were made, and the police have initiated an investigation, appealing to the public for witnesses.

Demolition started on a Kingsway building in October 2015, but has taken longer than expected due to an unexpected amount of asbestos. The site was purchased by the council as part of plans to turn Kingsway into a business district. All internal works are now completed, and scaffolding is in place for exterior demolition. The project is set to be finished by spring.

After losing due to a disputed goal-line decision, Rovers manager, Bowyer, appeals to Football League authorities to adopt goal-line technology, as used in the Premier League since 2013-14. Bowyer emphasizes the high stakes in this league and the need for clear, fair results. Fulham manager Symons, beneficiary of the controversial decision, also supports the use of goal-line technology, claiming it eradicates any uncertainty in the game.

A 19-year-old athlete was bought for £7.5m and signed a five-year deal with the top-flight champions. After impressing viewers at Euro 2016, he joined the Foxes in Stockholm and will play against Barcelona in a friendly match. The player is City manager Claudio Ranieri's fifth summer signing, following the previous additions of a goalkeeper, a defender, a midfielder, and a forward.

The Burrell Collection museum will close for a multi-million pound redevelopment project expected to complete by 2020. The building, which is no longer suitable for use, will get a new, energy-efficient roof. The upgrades will also include two new floors of exhibition space, allowing the public to view 90% of the 8,000 objects. Parts of the collection will be displayed at the Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery in Glasgow during the refurbishment.

Farmers supplying chickens to a poultry processing company have been receiving heating subsidies for their wood chip boilers, used to heat the buildings housing the chicks. Finance Minister Máirtín Ó Muilleoir raised concerns over the operation of the scheme, but the company denies any issues. The company has met with finance and economy officials to keep the Northern Ireland RHI scheme within budget and advocates for responsible use of heat.
A man's body was found in a field near Belsyde Avenue on Saturday around 11:25. The police are working to identify the man. A post-mortem examination is scheduled to uncover the cause of death.
